title: AS Level
subject: Computer Science AS Level: Cambridge International AS Level for Computer Science

5FD1D207635549C2B54DC8C9AD6A9120.description: understand the need for stub testing

3F4F6125ACD44221A2C254ED53DB2932.description: choose suitable data for white-box testing

361D247DC4854752BF2AC202025D2010.description: choose suitable data for black-box testing

42BDE1D923C3400F979C0A002CC003A1.description:
locate and identify the different types of errors:
– syntax errors
– logic errors
– run-time errors

FE4D6CB49B81432A9E1F7CA15F032AAA.description: show understanding of ways of exposing faults in programs and ways of avoiding faults

8015BF5676A14173A5A1AD62E236CB95.description:
describe features found in a typical Integrated Development Environment (IDE):
– for coding, including context-sensitive prompts
– for initial error detection, including dynamic syntax checks
– for presentation, including prettyprint, expand and collapse code blocks
– for debugging, including: single stepping, breakpoints, variables/expressions report window

3C1241B46EB04583A3C8D32231326C67.description: show understanding of how to write, translate, test and run a high-level language program

C3B7AD13EE6B47BFAE51594A9EB0CA00.description: show understanding of the design, coding and testing stages in the program development cycle

7C0A48E3F396439C957B42B6D711D349.description: write programs containing several components and showing good use of resources

98042853E4BF474987C4C74842A677EB.description:
use the terminology associated with procedures and functions: procedure/function header,
procedure/function interface, parameter, argument, return value
– given pseudocode will use the following structure for function defi nitions:
 FUNCTION  RETURNS  // function has no
 parameters
 
 ENDFUNCTION
 FUNCTION  (: )
 RETURNS  // function has one or more parameters
 
 ENDFUNCTION
– a function is used in an expression, for example
○ x ← SQRT(n)
○ WHILE NOT EOF()

31145F9569A94E67829719BD4F4EB81A.description: explain where in the construction of an algorithm it is appropriate to use a function

31DF8B82A59640BC845B7969F52CEF44.description:
show understanding of passing parameters by value
 PROCEDURE  (BYVALUE : )
 
 ENDPROCEDURE
– a call is made to the procedure using CALL  ()

930771A504B5457986675D9A01A7E180.description:
show understanding of passing parameters by reference
 PROCEDURE  (BYREF : )
 
 ENDPROCEDURE

98A74AB18B4E44C2BA7165C53A330B8E.description:
explain where in the construction of an algorithm it would be appropriate to use a procedure
– given pseudocode will use the following structure for procedure defi nitions:
 PROCEDURE 
 
 ENDPROCEDURE
– a procedure may have none, one or more parameters
– a parameter can be passed by reference or by value

F44CC81FCA134BAAB7859BAC98C012D6.description: use the information provided in technical documentation describing functions/procedures

BAB19F3082B6409088E8B08136DEC352.description:
use a subset of the built-in functions and library routines supported by the chosen programming
language. This should include those used for:
– string/character manipulation
– formatting of numbers
– random number generator

C4548B0339C3420D9AC0D4D2CC370C76.description: justify why one loop structure may be better suited to a problem than the others

CC44CABA5F2C4A33B4168DF5CDA0488F.description:
use a ‘pre-condition’ loop
– given pseudocode will use the following structure:
 WHILE 
 
 ENDWHILE

124608BB24EC44029F5A9892DC0E621A.description:
use a ‘post-condition’ loop:
– given pseudocode will use the following structure:
 REPEAT
 
 UNTIL

DE510F214F034841A37D0F3ADFD4C2F3.description:
use a ‘count-controlled’ loop:
– given pseudocode will use the following structure:
 FOR  ←  TO 
 
 ENDFOR
– alternatively:
 FOR  ←  TO  STEP 
 
 ENDFOR

4DA015280EED49969809093693595F6F.description:
use a ‘CASE’ structure
– given pseudocode will use the following structure:
 CASE OF 
 : 
 : 
 ...
 ENDCASE
– alternatively:
 CASE OF 
 : 
 : 
 ...
 OTHERWISE 
 ENDCASE

34AE94901C66421E8A7093B5A7BC67C9.description:
use an ‘IF’ structure including the ‘ELSE’ clause and nested IF statements
– given pseudocode will use the following structure:
 IF 
 THEN
 
 ENDIF
– or, including an ‘else’ clause:
 IF 
 THEN
 
 ELSE
 
 ENDIF

8F2B798A1E6D418C9F441B4327841632.description: appreciate that program coding is a transferable skill

D05FAA5AF4644B2CA8CB1F8A4E60C728.description:
recognise the basic control structures in a high-level language other than the one chosen to be
studied in depth

D295D9D63BB24956B52B55A3653B9917.description:
write program statements for:
– the declaration of variables and constants
– the assignment of values to variables and constants
– expressions involving any of the arithmetic or logical operators
– input from the keyboard and output to the console
 given pseudocode will use the following structures:
 DECLARE  :  // declaration
 CONSTANT  = 
  ←  or  // assignment
 INPUT 
 OUTPUT 
 OUTPUT

BDB84FB4F1C8477CA04603B7B61B4AE8.description:
implement and write a program from a given design presented as either a program flowchart or
pseudocode

FF41EE5C504645079BB0263F26052D2D.description: write a program in a high-level language

EBC319A91BA84D8FA416643F3D123B41.description: write program code for simple file handling of a text fi le, consisting of several lines of text

A8B623F4EC3A43D2A47251567AC25C09.description: use pseudocode for file handling: OPENFILE  FOR READ/WRITE/APPEND // Open file (understand the difference between various file modes) READFILE , // Read a line of text from the file WRITEFILE , // Write a line of text to the file CLOSEFILE  // Close file EOF() // function to test for the end of the file

3E48C59A94B64772A1D4039EC6AA6629.description: show understanding of why files are needed

F808A921683D4C528493FDE55194CD65.description:
given pseudocode will use the following structures:
 DECLARE  : ARRAY[:] OF 
 DECLARE  : ARRAY[:,[:]
OF

C73B5235C93744AE94C268B769302910.description:
write algorithms/program code to process array data including:
– sorting using a bubble sort
– searching using a linear search

EBF32E8211914C7491CF46FC53F3FA8D.description: write program code using 1D and 2D arrays

4A5C50D52AB64EBEB0114ADEBABCF26E.description:
use pseudocode for 1D and 2D arrays (pseudocode will use square brackets to contain the array
subscript, for example a 1D array as A[1:n] and a 2D array as C[1:m, 1:n])

F2B9B524C80D4BBF8612ABBFA023C293.description: select a suitable data structure (1D or 2D array) to use for a given task

798C835EDC924743A2484753C614AD7C.description: use the technical terms associated with arrays including upper and lower bound

B91DE4509BB8473A8D0B5BE329D22144.description:
show understanding of how character and string data are represented by software including the
ASCII and Unicode character sets

AE05A251437F45C19FE02E3990F9AF89.description:
use in practical programming the data types that are common to procedural high-level languages:
integer, real, char, string, Boolean, date (pseudocode will use the following data types:
 INTEGER, REAL, CHAR, STRING, BOOLEAN, DATE, ARRAY, FILE)

4D3077C2805F46B9AA687469CD7E08A7.description: select appropriate data types for a problem solution

2AA6982E02AF459C96B1B78B2FF2A40D.description: analyse an existing program and make amendments to enhance functionality

0A3EBD09C64E41B7B4A12D851B603D81.description: make amendments to an algorithm and data structure in response to specification changes

161D95275FBE4A96820C19E201912F5A.description: identify any error(s) in the algorithm by using the completed trace table

0C7E47CB696641F0995F4BC38757FEFC.description:
perform white-box testing by:
– selecting suitable data
– using a trace table

D90449E3CA3440058E6FE4617A0780A4.description: derive equivalent pseudocode from a structure chart

B43C4ED083DD4168BCE52EF08711E282.description: construct a structure chart for a given problem

50E5F7E29DB546EFBFCA19FEA30841EB.description: describe the purpose of a structure chart

2658E722F11C4EC7AB92B1D2E13B9918.description:
use a structure chart to express the parameters passed between the various modules/
procedures/functions which are part of the algorithm design

E99FA0ED889246CF955197AE7037CDD0.description: use logic statements to define parts of an algorithm solution

52575CCDF489479B8CB7F3A00BED6AEB.description: show an appreciation of why logic statements are used to define parts of an algorithm solution

EB524400F2A84E54A00D45BD75E0B639.description:
decompose a problem into sub-tasks leading to the concept of a program module (procedure/
function)

3DD73A870F3F4A6E84D4FA2BBAD3E6A5.description:
use the process of stepwise refinement to express an algorithm to a level of detail from which
the task may be programmed

98EF767355384F699A587C3F8B5F73AF.description: derive pseudocode from a given program flowchart or vice versa

F6777FDF97AF4845BA51A22E1A3DD280.description: derive pseudocode or a program flowchart from a structured English description of a problem

199410AB73274ADC8219A4CF72C66AFD.description:
document a simple algorithm using:
– structured English
– pseudocode (on the examination paper, any given pseudocode will be presented using the
Courier New font)
– program flowchart

5AC69FA359FA49778DA72AB7999238EC.description: show understanding that simple algorithms consist of input, process, output at various stages

F21038361D35482A9D593087AAE40040.description:
show understanding that many algorithms are expressed using the four basic constructs of
assignment, sequence, selection and repetition

9FB66EC0242041AA910C107F7FA1AE19.description: use suitable identifier names for the representation of data used by a problem – summarise identifier names using an identifier table

1B66FC7888E44B60A0F03F3B1CFC5C08.description: show understanding that an algorithm is a solution to a problem expressed as a sequence of defined steps

CB9C943DB516434FAE8C147002A2D64B.description:
show understanding that the industry standard for both DDL and DML is Structured Query
Language (SQL)
– show understanding of a given SQL script
– write simple SQL (DDL) commands using a sub-set of commands for:
○ creating a database (CREATE DATABASE)
○ creating a table defi nition (CREATE TABLE)
○ changing a table defi nition (ALTER TABLE)
○ adding a primary key or foreign key to a table (ADD PRIMARY KEY)
– write a SQL script for querying or modifying data (DML) which are stored in (at most two)
database tables
○ Queries:
○ SELECT, FROM, WHERE, ORDER BY, GROUP BY, INNER JOIN
– Data maintenance:
○ INSERT INTO, DELETE FROM, UPDATE

80B70F42114645F88E1396C83B3EFC4B.description: show understanding that DBMS software carries out: – all creation/modification of the database structure using its DDL – query and maintenance of data using its DML

C1DF2505832F4C419C877D4B1D955680.description: Data Definition Language (DDL) and Data Manipulation Language (DML)

B8FB77FD0ACB42B9ACC535A98BD9F765.description:
make the changes to a given set of tables which are not in 3NF to produce a solution in 3NF, and
justify the changes made

A0AE6DE3F75D409594DB9AB2A54B2E23.description: explain why a given set of database tables are, or are not, in 3NF

C6F43FD02E6A4AEE87D74BC964C3698D.description:
show understanding of the normalisation process: First (1NF), Second (2NF) and Third Normal
Form (3NF)

27122378C3AB405F95C0F698DDAD6417.description: use an entity-relationship diagram to document a database design

CBF41DAB286A4A3BAFD1F78823732FEC.description: produce a relational design from a given description of a system

F9AB92DC54F1430E9262FCDD48BE14BF.description:
show understanding of, and use, the terminology associated with a relational database model:
entity, table, tuple, attribute, primary key, candidate key, foreign key, relationship, referential
integrity, secondary key and indexing

5AB12101F9EC4C448C04F1FE1D624383.description:
show awareness that high-level languages provide accessing facilities for data stored in a
database

337EAB30737B41E09B39575511E551D0.description:
show understanding of how software tools found within a DBMS are used in practice:
– developer interface
– query processor

3457A743A5254B3EA593E98527DB5080.description:
show understanding of the features provided by a DBMS to address the issues of:
– data management, including maintaining a data dictionary
– data modelling
– logical schema
– data integrity
– data security, including backup procedures and the use of access rights to individuals/groups
of users

0DDE027F3CB1480D8526B395B4CBBE6D.description:
describe the features of a relational database which address the limitations of a file-based
approach

D60ECE02D62E4D97AD08FDF4A0EB9825.description:
show understanding of the limitations of using a file-based approach for the storage and retrieval
of data

83C43A79F6B14919B4682B00D63700D6.description:
show understanding of the implications of different types of software licensing: Free Software
Foundation, the Open Source Initiative, shareware and commercial software

1C6A12D3033B4C54AA4C09167FE4400F.description:
discuss measures to restrict access to data made available through the Internet and World Wide
Web

16CFD08FB7BA44B48301A7FEA554802A.description: describe the need for legislation to protect ownership, usage and copyright

65A1E5EA1559415EB014599D9C8B5534.description: show understanding of the concept of ownership and copyright

8E2B19F1811843F39039D8F400B46834.description:
show understanding of the need for a professional code of conduct for a computer system
developer

4879819489AD4F86A80FE301F1E459AE.description:
demonstrate the relevance of these principles to some typical software developer workplace
scenarios

5BFEA0AA2B274277A799B4B89B615066.description:
show understanding of the eight principles listed in the ACM/IEEE Software Engineering Code of
Ethics

8F3BD97573CC48738937510F9E3F9A95.description: explain how ethics may impact on the job role of the computing professional

65AC26A82B484BE9A6C565D9F562E336.description: show a basic understanding of ethics

F09BF853688746BEBEB6B29AB78626AC.description:
describe error detection and correction measures designed to protect the integrity of data,
including:
– data validation
– data verifi cation for data entry
– data verifi cation during data transfer, including
○ parity check
○ checksum check

E2C9389C8BEA42DBB82C7601E45AA79B.description: show awareness of what kind of errors can occur and what can be done about them

B86E9C4FB6BE4F139B9D615427022CEA.description:
describe security measures designed to protect the security of data, including:
– data backup
– a disk-mirroring strategy
– encryption
– access rights to data (authorisation)

5B240C1AB12444E39F19DD085357B3F5.description: describe security measures designed to protect computer systems, ranging from the stand-alone PC to a network of computers, including: – user accounts – firewalls – general authentication techniques, including the use of passwords and digital signatures

1469DBBCFD6C4C409D67F8C1BC1EB3BD.description:
show appreciation of the need for both the security of data and the security of the computer
system

FC51ED68D9B74D44AD7C39378ECFCF49.description: explain the difference between the terms security, privacy and integrity of data

3F1DB717D66C4722B8BCCFDE80699481.description:
show awareness that high-level language programs may be partially compiled and partially
interpreted, such as Java

54717106BB804A4FBEDE05A9950BDAFF.description: explain the benefits and drawbacks of using either a compiler or interpreter

5B4D2ED15F9C494F875C604B31F3580B.description:
show an understanding of the need for:
– assembler software for the translation of an assembly language program
– a compiler for the translation of a high-level language program
– an interpreter for execution of a high-level language program

7BEC51237B5B4D70A314B484CD92A32E.description: draw on experience of the writing of programs which include library routines

5BF6EC829E394C63B6F4FB72A1686F71.description:
describe the benefits to the developer of software constructed using library fi les, including
Dynamic Link Library (DLL) fi les

B29DD706E9574C58A4E987F1450780EE.description:
show an understanding that software under development is often constructed using existing code
from program libraries

CCBC8BBB15684571ABD015B21DE73088.description: show an understanding of the need for typical utility software used by a PC computer system: – disk formatter – virus checker – defragmenter software – disk contents analysis/disk repair software – file compression – backup software

7C152A96CF0C4A8FB9959B8F79B15F60.description: explain the key management tasks carried out by the operating system

1D0528F756AF447EBFED7E7E455F2BF7.description: describe why a computer system requires an operating system

9BAA946BCBCC45DFAC148A0D1A508EB5.description: trace a given simple assembly language program

F1D381E9705642B7A470BDF2D7917383.description:
describe the different stages of the assembly process for a ‘two-pass’ assembler for a given
simple assembly language program

CB7EFFA413C349AEBC56251A4E73A32A.description:
show understanding of the relationship between assembly language and machine code, including
symbolic and absolute addressing, directives and macros

9C1ABBD30BA4496AB0AE390B1D4D9D55.description:
show understanding that the set of instructions are grouped into instructions for:
– data movement (register to main memory and vice versa)
– input and output of data
– arithmetic operations
– unconditional and conditional jump instructions
– compare instructions
– modes of addressing: immediate, direct, indirect, indexed, relative

7439299256EB48EAB7814A6DD093E251.description: describe the stages of the fetch-execute cycle

661E22EBB7C94A9CBBE034AC7CF71D87.description:
show understanding of the need for ports, for example Universal Serial Bus (USB), to provide the
connection to peripheral devices

F1B563E791044EAE8ED2389639560BD4.description:
show understanding of how the bus width and clock speed are factors that contribute to the
performance of the computer system

B7383715A54D4193A0CD3DB184AE191F.description:
show understanding of how data are transferred between various components of the computer
system using the address bus, data bus and control bus

1BD570A257ED496E8255CE7F8D07BB8E.description:
show understanding of the roles carried out by the Arithmetic and Logic Unit (ALU), Control Unit
and system clock

E439A3B1FAF04F22AB152B2D2F6AB8FF.description:
show understanding of the roles carried out by registers, including the difference between
general purpose and special purpose registers: Program Counter, Memory Data Register,
Memory Address Register, Index Register, Current Instruction Register and Status Register

8A3BA09A1B6A4563A76947E8598A1844.description:
show understanding of the basic Von Neumann model for a computer system and the stored
program concept

C5378EFA6804477688F55F8E683957E2.description:
show understanding that some circuits can be constructed with fewer gates to produce the same
outputs

FC485DF638B44A73801730CB2EA7F907.description:
construct a truth table from either:
– a logic circuit
– a logic expression

20F54475717E44638CEBB8DA91DA2740.description:
construct a logic circuit from either:
– a problem statement
– a logic expression

42A0D8D20E054E509CD250B1FED0449F.description: construct the truth table for each of the logic gates above

30FFE0215F27497EA20B0C8AE12B137F.description:
understand and define the functions of NOT, AND, OR, NAND, NOR and XOR (EOR) gates
including the binary output produced from all the possible binary inputs

245E33C9CB89443690484ACDA5028572.description: use the following logic gate symbols: NOT/ AND/ OR/ NAND/ NOR/ XOR

487D351DAC954D6EA9378E4BC8C84ACB.description:
show understanding of the need for primary storage
– explain the differences between RAM and ROM memory
– explain the differences between Static RAM (SRAM) and Dynamic RAM (DRAM)

091F06A2024E49958DE9E05F8C5CCABF.description: show understanding of the need for secondary (including removable) storage

C7AF3EDABB2244EA8136406A2546C43F.description: show understanding of the basic internal operation of the following specific types of device: – keyboard – speakers – trackerball mouse – hard disk – optical mouse – solid state (flash) memory – scanner – optical discs – inkjet printer – microphone – laser printer – touchscreen – 3D printer

9239E9D2AF694EEE94B05705211482BE.description: identify hardware devices used for input, output, secondary storage

592CD1E50D4C4BAFBACF8B9F04539FE3.description:
describe the sequence of events executed by the client computer and web server when a web
page consisting only of HTML tags is requested and displayed by a browser
– Client-side
○ recognise and identify the purpose of some simple JavaScript code
○ describe the sequence of events executed by the client computer and web server when a
web page with embedded client-side code is requested and displayed by a browser
○ show understanding of the typical use of client-side code in the design of an application
– Server-side
○ recognise and identify the purpose of some simple PHP code
○ describe the sequence of events executed by the client computer and web server when a
web page with embedded server-side code is requested and displayed by a browser
○ show understanding that an appropriately designed web application for accessing
database data makes use of server-side scripting

7AC547D7BB134A9EBECD54E98D014520.description:
explain how a Uniform Resource Locator (URL) is used to locate a resource on the World Wide
Web (WWW) and the role of the Domain Name Service

1DA5ED04AE1642DBA9A9E46CA7AE7B18.description:
explain the difference between a public IP address and a private IP address and the implication for
security

CBC88BA3ACB34BA69037BB0B23F1DA46.description:
explain the format of an IP address and how an IP address is associated with a device on a
network

C7B225B76AC54BCEB2823B45075003AA.description: show understanding of the importance of bit rates/broadband speed on bit streaming

CDAB9E09572140FE90A17082C7D62F8C.description: show understanding of bit streaming (both real-time and on-demand)

C393B699BB0244F084DC5058653E7605.description: explain the benefits and drawbacks of using copper cable, fibre-optic cabling, radio waves, microwaves, satellites

D1525E0E644A490383C3A3E7D15DC176.description:
explain how communication systems are used to support the Internet: The Public Switched
Telephone Network (PSTN), dedicated lines, cell phone network

E86486E359604DE1AE9B877B6384C4C5.description: explain how hardware is used to support the Internet: networks, routers, gateways, servers

2EC05C4FA69845D598F167FC7D82AB33.description: describe what is meant by the World Wide Web (WWW) and the Internet

349CDE6598B243CEA16C2C59045AA188.description: give examples of applications which use the client-server model

2C171977305542FE8951D1282977D1E9.description: explain the client-server model of networked computers

D3525CC1E1374C9888B7623F119BA939.description: show understanding of how digital data can be compressed, using either ‘lossless’ (including run length encoding – RLE) or ‘lossy’ techniques

1BA616C4499747B6BBBD27D656AF9243.description:
Show understanding of the characteristics of video streams:
– the frame rate (frames/second)
– interlaced and progressive encoding
– video interframe compression algorithms and spatial and temporal redundancy
– multimedia container formats

8EB4055C70DA49CBA20683D946B12903.description: show understanding of how typical features found in sound editing software are used in practice

B87E428C4B8E4E0AB1DA63C070267613.description: show understanding of how fi le sizes depend on sampling rate and sampling resolution

785688A7D402475DA8180445F5B1F98A.description: use the associated terminology: sampling, sampling rate, sampling resolution

E71D60E5427B42C09FDF8A6A8F108B7F.description: show understanding of how sound is represented and encoded

3E9DAAAD34B6486192EBDD44CE216ED6.description: justify where bitmapped graphics and/or vector graphics are appropriate for a given task

0581C13A4D354153B54425971D47BFDF.description:
show understanding of how typical features found in bitmapped and vector graphics software are
used in practice

FCC4CD146A4F47CFB40E347A62FF9D08.description: use the terminology associated with vector graphics: drawing object, property and drawing list

0C1DA715072940EBAC3F23322CF83F32.description: show understanding of how data for a vector graphic is represented and encoded

D6FFBB0E0E2A424DA8CDC8AFD33FAB99.description: perform calculations estimating the file size for bitmapped images of different resolutions

BE59937432124868A7F71D793D24C4D4.description: use the terminology associated with bitmaps: pixel, file header, image resolution, screen resolution

557E34315268474ABDA6DCD7A00FE4A5.description: show understanding of how data for a bitmapped image is encoded

78727C6018EC4E3298D160CCD2C13EBC.description: describe practical applications where BCD is used

1F5441AB78894AFA89F18D300C322450.description: express a denary number in Binary Coded Decimal (BCD) and vice versa

9CC1965B8ECC45CFA5DD43010F525D4C.description:
show understanding of, and be able to represent, character data in its internal binary form
depending on the character set used (Candidates will not be expected to memorise any particular
character codes but must be familiar with ASCII and Unicode.)

BCBC4708B2864F66B8DAFA284D50C4A5.description: express a positive or negative integer in two’s complement form

8E358C064EC048CE8033677347E12C30.description: convert a number from one number system to another

EA90D2509016476D8D9BC723DF615BB1.description:
show understanding of the basis of different number systems and use the binary, denary and
hexadecimal number system
